text: It's great to see various 'manifestos' here. Based on this discussion I'm trying to extract the 'values' from various notes I have - though I'm not sure what qualifies as a 'value' (vs a design goal or principle). One value/aspiration I have is that 'programming should be tangible and live'. The broader theme perhaps is 'dont make me simulate the computer'. My post about that is here: <http://shalabh.com/programmable-systems/wheres-my-simulator.html|shalabh.com/programmable-systems/wheres-my-simulator.html>

elements.text: It's great to see various 'manifestos' here. Based on this discussion I'm trying to extract the 'values' from various notes I have - though I'm not sure what qualifies as a 'value' (vs a design goal or principle). One value/aspiration I have is that 'programming should be tangible and live'. The broader theme perhaps is 'dont make me simulate the computer'. My post about that is here:

text:
I like spreadsheets as a starting point - they have affordances that expose the single level structure clearly and make discovery easier. Also you can represent a few different views of the contents in the same medium, unlike text blob editing. Once you go into a cell you're still back to text though.

I think what I was trying to get at earlier is the contrast between the 'program' and the 'system'. Using 'programs' is only one of many possible way to desing and build a larger 'system'. Could there be other ways to decompose and build/modify a system? Could I, for instance, have a model where I explore a system to easily discover the various componenets (and sub-components and so on), and when I find what i'm looking for, modify it 'in-place'. The 'component' modified here might be very small, e.g. equivalent to a function. This is very different from what it takes to modify a single function in a large running system today. Everything from discovery, explorability to update requires knowledge of various intermediate systems (source control, build systems, compilers, deployment systems, 'the process model').

<https://medium.com/what-to-build/human-values-a-quick-primer-b01ef9617925>

elements.text: This might be a little bit too far down the rabbit hole, but a good answer to the question “What are values?” can be found here:

text: <@U5STGTB3J> those questions seem good for reflecting on any values.

elements.text: those questions seem good for reflecting on any values.

text: <@U8A5MS6R1> Speaking of reflection, the kind of liveness you describe seems to emerge as online/interactive visualization/representation tools applied to a system capable of reflective awareness.  I just mean you can ask, "hey computer, what are you doing?"  In as much as the representation involves analysis and automated feedback, you end up with a sort of consciousness.  (Not to be confused with the phenomenological, first person subjective feeling of being consciously aware.)  I just want to point out that experience of live model has many parts.

elements.text: Speaking of reflection, the kind of liveness you describe seems to emerge as online/interactive visualization/representation tools applied to a system capable of reflective awareness.  I just mean you can ask, "hey computer, what are you doing?"  In as much as the representation involves analysis and automated feedback, you end up with a sort of consciousness.  (Not to be confused with the phenomenological, first person subjective feeling of being consciously aware.)  I just want to point out that experience of live model has many parts.

text: And, friends, is it liveness itself that we value or is it liveness in the service of, say, comprehension?  I like liveness for its own sake,  feeling connected, in the moment, jacked in.  For comprehension, I recall a prodigious engineer capable of feely navigating swaths of Google – more like teleporting through it – armed with no more than a single large terminal window.  In as much as comprehension is our goal, practices to improve our own thought patterns may be the best path.

elements.text: And, friends, is it liveness itself that we value or is it liveness in the service of, say, comprehension?  I like liveness for its own sake,  feeling connected, in the moment, jacked in.  For comprehension, I recall a prodigious engineer capable of feely navigating swaths of Google – more like teleporting through it – armed with no more than a single large terminal window.  In as much as comprehension is our goal, practices to improve our own thought patterns may be the best path.
